div.p: A PATTERNE OF POPISH PEACE. OR A Peace of Papists with Protestants.
BEGINNING IN ARticles, Leagues, Oathes, and a Marriage.
And ending in a bloudy Massacre of many thousand Protestants.
LONDON. Printed by L. N. for RICHARD WHITAKER, and are to be sold at his shop in Paul's Church-yard at the signe of the Kings Armes. 1644.

div.head: To the Reader, that is wise already, or that he may be wise.
div.p:
ASKE and enquire what are the things of highest, most solemne, and sacred Obligation, that may call for trust in the way of peace betweene the sons of men, and when you have found them, then have you found those very things, of which Papists, and popishly affected do make nets and snares to deceive Trust; and to destroy those that trust them; Be they Treaties, Leagues, Oathes, Marriages:
These, even these sacred bonds of a secure peace, are those that are turned into cords and fetters to bind those that trust them to an assured ruine and Destruction. So they are not safe, because in their nature they draw Trust, but because they draw trust, they are dangerous, for by that Trust they doe deceive. Then by what Security can any be assured of any Peace with Papists, when the very Security doth Deceit, and Destroy? Beleeve it therefore, that nothing under heaven but Power, can make you safe from Papists: For if they gaine Trust from you, and you leave Power to them; you may see
in the Papists of Ireland, what their fellowes would do in England; when they had nothing to complain of, but too much liberty for an Idolatrous Religion; yet withall having too much Power, they took advantage of that Power for an Irish Massacre of English Protestants. Surely now in all the Kingdomes which this Crown carries in the Title of it, the Popish plot of warre and murder hath had bloudy passage, England, Scotland, France and Ireland. But let not us become Nurses to such a Crimson brat, by gaining it the white milke of a weake and simple Peace. But where Trnst without Power would betray and
destroy us, there let Power without any Trust (below that wherby the highest above will strengthen our Power) secure us. And to keepe us close to this Rule; let the patterne of this Peace, made by French popery, stand like a Pyramide before our eyes: And when you see it, heare it it also; for it speaks, and that which it speakes is this, Pray and provide; That the peace of French popery be not translated into English, by English Protestants.

div.head: A Declaration of the furious outrages of France, with the slaughter of the Admirall.
div.p:
IT were to be wished that the memory of the fresh slaughters, and of that butcherly murthering that hath lately been committed in a manner in all the townes of France, were utterly put out of the minds of men: for so much dishonour, and so great infamie hath thereby stained the whole French Nation, that the most part of them are now ashamed of their own countrey, defiled with two most filthy spots, falshood and cruelty. Of the which, whether hath been the greater, it is hard to say. But for asmuch as there flie every where abroad Pamphlets
written by flatterers of the Court, and men corruptly hired for reward, which do most shamefully set out things fained and falsly imagined, in stead of truth, I thought my selfe bound to do this service to posterity, to put the matter in writing as it was truly done indeed, being well inabled to have knowledge thereof, both by mine owne calamity, and by those that with their owne eyes beheld a great part of the same slaughters.

In the yeare of our Lord 1561. when there seemed to be some perill of troubles to arise by reason of the multitude of such as embraced the Religion (which they call Reformed) for before that time the usuall manner of punishing such as durst professe that Religion, was besides losse and forfeiture of all their goods to the Kings use, to burne their bodies, at the request of the great Lords and Nobility, there was holden an assembly of the Estates in the Kings house at Saint
Germains in Lay, neare to the City of Paris, at which Assembly, in presence, and with the Royall assent, of King Charles the ninth, A decree for the exercise of Religion in publike meetings, whereupon a cruell Massacre. it was decreed, that from thenceforth it should not be prejudiciall to any man to professe the said Religion, and that it should be lawfull for them to have publike meetings and preachings for the exercise thereof, but in the Suburbs of Townes only.

At this Assembly Francis Duke of Guise, being descended of the House of Loraine, and at that time Grand Master of the Kings Household, was not present. But when he was enformed of this Decree, he boyled with incredible sorrow and anger, and within few dayes after at a little Towne in Champagne called Vassey, while the Professors of the said Religion were there at a Sermon, he, accompanied with a band of souldiers, set upon them, and slew men and women to the number of two hundred.

There was among these of the religion (for so hereafter according to the usuall phrase of the French tongue wee intend to call them) Lewis of Burbon of the bloud Royall, commonly called Prince of Conde, after the name of a certaine Towne, a man of great power by reason of his kindred to the King. Therefore when the Duke of Guise most vehemently strived against that law, and as much as in him lay, did utterly overthrow it, and troubled the common quiet thereby stablished, Gasper de Coligni Admirall of France, and Francis de Andelot his brother, Captain of the Fantary, and other Princes, Noblemen and Gentlemen of the same Religion, come daily by heapes to the Prince of Conde, to complaine of the outragious boldnesse and untemperate violence of the Duke of Guise.

At that time Katherine de Medices, Pope Clements brothers daughter, and mother of King
Charles, borne in Florence a Citie of Italie, had the governance of the Realme in the Kings minority. For though by the law of France, neither the inheritance nor the administration of the Realme is granted to women, yet through the cowardly negligence of Anthony King of Navarre, the said Katherine de Medices the Kings mother, aganst the custome of the realme, was joyned with him in that office of Protectorship. She fearing the presumption and fierce pride of the Guisans, The Qu. mothers Letters to the Prince of Conde. wrote to the Prince of Conde with her owne hand: which letters are yet remaining, and at the assemblie of the Princes of Germany at Franckford, holden under Ferdinand the Emperour, were produced and openly read about ten yeares past: wherin she earnestly besought him in so great hardnesse and distresse not to for sake her, but to account both the mother and the children, that is, both her selfe and the King, and the Kings brethren,
committed to his faith and naturall kindnesse, and that he should with all speede, provide for their common safety: assuring him, that she would so imprint in the Kings mind his travell in that behalfe, that he should never be loser by it.

Within few dayes after the Duke of Guise wel-knowing how great authority the name of the King would carry in France, The policie of the Duke of Guise to get the King into his power, that he might the better effect his wicked enterprizes. and to the intent that he would not seeme to attempt any thing rather of his own head than by the privity of the king, and having attained fit partners to joyn with him in these enterprises, he got the King into his power. Which thing being known abroad, and many hard encombrances therupon suddenly rising, and a great part of the nobility of France marvellously troubled with it, the Prince of Conde by advise of his friends, thought it best for him to take certaine townes and furnish them with garrisons: which was the beginning of the first civill war.
For the Prince of Conde alleaged the cause of his taking armes, The beginning and cause of the first Civil war. to be the defence of the Kings Edict, wherein consisted the safety of the common weale, and that it could not be repealed without most assured undoing of the nation of France, and destruction of the nobility, by reason of the exceeding great multitude of those that daily joyned themselves to that Religion: Of which number such as being of noble birth, or were in power, dignity, wealth, and credit above the rest, thought it not meet for them to suffer the punishments and cruelties accustomed to be extended on the professors thereof; beside that, they held themselves discontented that the Duke of Guise one newly come, a stranger, translated from the forrests of Loraine into France, would take upon him in France so great courage and so high dominion and power. Therto was added the Queene mothers singular care (as was reported) for conservation
of peace and repressing the rage of the Guisians. Upon which opinion it is certian that above twenty thousand men having regard onely to the Queenes inclination, joyned themselves to the side of those of the Religion, and to the defence of their profession, which at that time had besiged the force of the Kings power.

After certaine battailes and many losses on both parts, The Duke of Guise slaine, whereupon a peace concluded, with condition of free exercise of Religion. The injuries done to the Protestants by the Papists continually notwithstanding the Peace. and the Duke of Guise slain, within a yeare, peace was made with this condition, that they of the Religion should have free liberty thereof, and should have assemblies and preachings for the exercise of the same in certaine places.

This peace continued in force, but not in all places, during five yeares: for in the most townes and jurisdictions, the Officers that were affectionate to the Romish side, whom they commonly call Catholikes, did all the displeasures they could to those of the Religion.
Therefore, when Ferdizando Alvares de Toledo, commony called Duke of Alva, was leading an armie not farre from the frontiers of France, against those of the low countrey which embraced the reformed Religion, The Qu. mother obtains an armie of Switzers under a false pretence of defence, to oppresse the Prince of Conde, & the Admirall, and the other Protestants. against the will of the King of Spaine, the Queene mother caused to be levied and brought in to France sixe thousand Switzers for a defence (as she caused it to be bruted) but as the successe hath proved, for this intent, that the Prince of Conde, the Admirall and other noble men of the Religion, if they escaped the treason prepared for them, and listed to defend them selves by force, and trie it by battell, might be suddenly oppressed ere they were provided. For the courtiers wch then had the managing of these matters, did not at that time well trust the souldiers of France. Many things pertaining to the course of that time, and the renewing of the warre, must here for hast to our present purpose be necessarily omitted.

When the warre had endured about sixe months, peace was made with the same conditions that we have above rehearsed, that all men should have free libertie to follow and professe the Religion reformed. For this was ever one and the last condition upon all the warres. But within few dayes or months after, The treachery of the Peace. it was plainly vnderstood, that the same peace was full of guile and treason, and finaly, that it was no peace, but most cruell war cloaked under the name of peace. For forthwith all those townes which they of the Religion had yelded up, were possessed and strengthened with garrisons of souldiers of the contrary side, saving one Towne on the sea-coast in the parts of Xantoigne commonly called Rochell. For the men of that towne about two hundred yeares before, had yelded themselves to the Kings power and allegiance, with this cōdition, that they should never be constrained against their
will to receive any garrison souldiers.

Also the Princes of Conde and the Admirall were advertised; Advertisement of treason against the Prince of Conde, & the Admirall, by Tavaignes made Marshall of France hereupon. that there was treason againe prepared to intrap them by Tavaignes, a mā given to murther and mischiefe, which had lately been made Marshall of France, and that if they did not speedely avoyde the same, it should shortly come to passe, that they should be deceived and taken by him, and delivered up to the crueltie of their adversaries.

Upon the receit of these advertisments, they immediatly make hast to Rochell, carying with them their wives and young children, The beginning of a third civill warre which was the beginning of the third civill warre, the most sharpe and miserable of all the rest.

There was at that time in the Court, Charles Cardinall of Lorain, brother to the Duke of Guise, which (as is above said,) was slayne in the first war, one accompted most subtill and craftie of all
the rest, but of a terrible, cruell and troublesome disposition, and thought intollerable even at Rome it selfe. This man, they of the reformed Religion reported to be the most sharpe and hatefull enemy of their profession, and him they abhorred above all other for the cruelty of his nature, and named him the firebrand of all civill flames. He at the beginning of the third civill war, Notwithstanding the Kings former Edicts by the perswasion of Charles Cardinall of Lorain, he publisheth an Edict, that no man professe any Religion but the Romish. perswaded the King to publish an Edict, that no man professe any Religion but the Romish or Popish, and that whosoever should imbrace any other, should be accompted as traytours. In that same Edict Printed at Paris, this sentence was expressely conteynd, and for the strangenesse of the matter, and for that it stained the Kings name with the most dishonorable spot of perjurie and breach of faith, it was in other impressions afterward omitted. And it was further then declared, that albeit the King had in many Edictes before that time
permitted the freedome of Religion, yet his meaning ever was to retaine and cause to be retained of all men, the onely Romish or popish Religion within his Realme.

After many overthrowes on both partes given and received, whereas the end of this third warre was thought likely to be the harder, by reason of the breach of faith in the yeares before, and on the other side the state of the Realme by reason of the waste that the Cities were brought unto, and extreme poverty of the meane people and husbandmen, did require some treatie of composition, the King sent messengers to the Admirall, Civill Peace propounded upon pretence of joyning against a forraigne enemy. to signifie unto him in the Kings name, that the King himselfe had at length found out a most sure way of peace and concord, namely that the armies of both partes joyned together, should goe into the low countrey against the Duke of Alva which had been the author of the late calamities in France. He signified
further, that he had great causes of quarrels against the King of Spayne, and this principally, that he had invaded and held by force, an Island of the newfound Land called Florida, which had been taken by the French, and kept under his dominion, suddenly slaying all the souldiers there: & likewise the Marquesdome of Finall, the inhabitants wherof had but a little time before, yeelded thēselves to the Kings subjection and allegeance. He said that the most stedfast band of concord should be that forren war, and that there could no other better meane be devised to drowne the memory of the former dissentions in eternall forgetfulnesse.

To the performance hereof, he said it was a matter of most apt opportunity, that Lodovick Count of Nassaw, brother to to the Prince of Aurenge, had been now two yeers in the Admiralls camp, to whome the Admirall gave principall credit in all things, and that by him and
his fellowes of the low country, & others whom he understood to favour his part, it might easily bee brought to passe that certaine Cities might be surprised. and thereby great advantage be attained to the atchieving of the war.

The Admirall hearing these things was marvellously troubled. For albeit he doubted not of the Kings fidelity, yet therwithall many things fell into his minde to be considered: as the power of the Cardinall and rest of the Guisians, who were well knowne to have been at all times most affectionate to the King of Spayne. For the Duke of Guise had left a sonne, a very yong man, called Henry, to whom the Queene had given all the offices and places of honor that his father had borne before, being unfit thereto by age, and against the ancient lawes and customes, and also through the traiterous infidelity of certaine of the Kings counsell, whom she knew for their
affection to Popish Religion, to be most addicted to the Spanish King and that divers of them had great yeerely pensions of him, and did disclose unto him the affaires of the Realme. The Admirals snares in the undertaking of this war. He remembred how hereby it came to passe, that the same Kings Embassador (which among strange nations seemed vtterly incredible) was admitted into the privie Counsell of France, and that one Biragio a Lumbard, and (as it is reported) a traytour to his owne countrey, otherwise altogether vnlearned, and specially ignorant of the civill Law, was yet for the subtilty of his wit advanced to so great honour, that he executed the Chancellours office, Michael Hospitall being displaced, a man knowne to be such a one, as there was not in all degrees of men any either more wise, or more learned, or more zelously loving his countrey. Here withall he considered the slanderous cavillations of his adversaries, to whom hereby might seem
an occasion given, as if the Admirall were of a troublesome nature, and could not abide any quietnesse, nor could long rest at home without some tumultuous stir. Hereunto the messiengers replyed as they were able, and therewithall alleaged this cause of so sodaine hatred against the Spanish King, that one Albenie late returned out of Spaine, had informed the King and the Queene mother for certainty, that King Philip a few moneths before, had poysoned his wife the French Kings sister, and had spred rumors of her thoroughout all Spaine, such as for the honour of many persons are meet not to be disclosed. But nothing moved the Admirall so much as the cheerful earnestness of Lodovick of Nassaw, who as soone as he was advertised of that purpose of the King, omitted nothing that he thought might serve to encourage the Admirall thereunto.

The Admirall perswaded hereby nothing fearing the infidelity of
those of the Court, The Admirall not fearing infidelity, harkens to a composition. Peace concluded with condition of liberty to use the Religion. gave his mind to harken to composition. And so was the third civill warre ended, and the peace concluded with the same conditions that were before, that every man should have free liberty to use and professe the Religion.

Within few monthes after this, divers Princes of Germany, that favoured the Religion reformed, and among those the three Electors, the Palsgrave, the Duke of Saxony, and the Marquesse of Brandeburge, sent their Embassadours into France to the King, to gratulate vnto him for the new reconciliation of his Subjects. And because they accompted it greatly to behove them selves that the same concord should remaine stedfast and of long continuance, they promised, that if any would for that cause procure trouble, or make war upon him either within his owne dominions, or without, they and their followers should be ready to defend him. To this Embassage the King first by
words, The Kings subscription, and faith given, sacredly to observe the pacification. and afterward by a booke subscribed with his own hand, answered and gave his faith, that he would for ever most sacredly and faithfully observe his Edict of pacification.

Hereby so much the more willingly the Admirall suffered himself to be drawn to the said purposes for the Low-countrey, although oftentimes calling to mind the nature of the Queen mother, he used to say to divers, and specially to Theligny, to whom he afterward maried his daughter, that he greatly suspected the rolling wit of that woman. For (said he) so soone as she hath brought us into that preparation against the Low-countrey, she will leave us in the midst.

Neverthelesse, the Count of Nassaw writeth to his brother, and they conferring their advises together, send messengers to the King, that if it please him to deale with the matter of the Low-countrey, they will shortly so doe, that hee
shall by their many and great services, well perceive their affection and devotion toward him. The King writeth againe to them in most loving termes, saying that their Message most highly pleased him, and he gave to them both his hearty thanks.

About the same time Maximilian the Emperour pitying the estate of the Prince of Aurenge (as he said) treated by his Embassadours with the King of Spaine, and had in maner obtained, that the Prince should have all his goods restored unto him, but with this condition, that he should have no house within the territory of the low countrie, but settling his residence and dwelling elsewhere, he should freely enjoy all his revenewes. Which matter being reported to the French King, he immediatly sent messengers to the Prince of Aurenge willing him to looke for nothing by that dealing of the Emperour, saying that it was but a fraud and guileful device
intended for this purpose, onely to breake up his levying of souldiers that he had begun in Germanie: and assuring him, that if he would credit and follow him, hee would give him aid sufficient to recover his estate.

The Prince of Aurenge perswaded by these promises of King Charles, continued his musters, and determined a while to bear the charges though they were heavy to him, while such things as were necessary for the warre, were in preparing. In the meane time Lodovick in disguised apparel went to Paris to the King. Forasmuch as the season of the yeare by this time seemed not commodious to levy an armie, for the winter was at hand, by assent they deferred the matter till the next summer.

These things thus hanging, the Prince of Aurenge his captaines by sea, did oftentimes set upon the Spanyards and Portugals, and such ships as they took they brought into
the haven of Rochell, which then was in the power of the Prince of Condees part: and there they openly vttered and sould their prizes to the men of the towne and other merchants of France, whereupon the Embassadour of Spaine made often complaints to the Kings privy councell.

And forasmuch as they thought it very avaylable to this enterprise, that Elizabeth Queene of England might be brought into league with them, the King commited the dealing in that matter to the Admirall. For, The Admirals honourable entertainment at the Court. a few moneths before, the King had with most sweet alluring letters, gotten him to the Court, where he was most honorably entertained: and to take from him all occasion of distrust upon his adversaries, or of otherwise suspecting of the Kings or Queene mothers affection towards him, first, all the Guisians of a set purpose departed the Court then the King gave the Admirall free liberty to
take with him what company and what furniture he would: and because it was thought that he had more confidence in the Marshall Cosse, then in the rest, therefore the King commanded the said Marshall to be ever at hand with the Admirall, and to assist him in the Kings name if any need were.

The matter of the league with England, the Admiral so diligently and industriously handled, that within short space after by Embassadours sent, The League with England solemnely confirmed. And the first and chiefest condition, liberty of Religion and the observation of the Edict of Pacification. and by faith given and received, and oathes solemnly taken on both parts, it was confirmed. Concerning the procurement of other leagues and amities, such as might seem to further the enterprise of the low country, the Admirall also travelled in the Kings name, and by his commandement, and had in a manner brought all these things to an end. And of all those leagues, the first and principall condition was, that the liberty of Religion should continue, and that
the King should most diligently and sincerely observe this Edict of pacification.

Though these things seemed to be handled secretly, yet by the letters both of Biragio the Vicechancellor, of whom we made mention before, and of Morvilliers whem for his hypocriticall leanenesse, children commonly called the Chimera or Bugge of the Court, and by advertisements of Cardinall de Pelve, a man most fit either to invent or execute any treason, they were carried to the Bishop of Rome, The Popes Embassador to the King of France, with his Embassage. who by advise of his Cardinals sent by & by one of their number, called Alexandrine, in the midst of most sharp winter into France, with these instructions, to perswade the King to enter into the society of the league of Trent, whereof the first and principall article was, that the confederats should joyne their powers and make war upon the Turks and Heretikes, meaning by the name of
Heretikes, all those Princes that did permit the vse of the reformed Religion within their dominions.

The Cardinall Alexandrine was honourably received in the court, but yet dismissed without atchieving his purpose. For so was it bruited among the people, and commonly beleeved through-out France: albeit he himselfe secretly seemed to returne very merry and cheerfull to the Pope: and as it is reported, did sometime say that he received such answer of the King as was not to be published, and that the King and Queene mother had largely satisfied him.

Forasmuch as it was thought a matter greatly avayling to the enterprise of the low countrey, to send certaine ships into the English Seas that if any aid should be sent into the low countrey to the Duke of Alva out of Spaine, it might so be stopped, Strozza and the Baron de la Guard were appointed for that purpose, to whom the King gave
in commandement to rigge forth certaine ships of Burdeaux and Rochell, well armed and well appoynted, and to provide with all speede all things needfull for those ships. The Ambassadour of Spayne somewhat moved with this preparation, made divers complaints to the Kings counsell on the behalfe of the King his master, and yet never received any other answer, but that the King thought it not likely, and that he would send Commissioners to Burdeaux and to Rochel, with letters and commandement that there should be no preparation made to the sea, and if any had been made, it should be enquired of. what instructions were secretly and closely underhand given to these two captaines of that navie, we do not certainely know. But this no man can doubt of, but that they had commission to seize upon all ships wherein any Spanish souldiers should be transported into the low-countrey, and that all this preparation
to the sea, was ordained against the Spanish King and the Duke of Alva.

And moreover that the Admiral at the same time received commandement from the King, to send espials into Peru, an Island of the new found world, most plentiful of gold above all the other, now-being in the Spanyards dominion, to learne, if there were any good enterprise to be attempted or atchived for the getting of it. Which matter was committed to a certaine gentleman, one of the Admirals trayne, who went thither accompanyed with a certaine Portingal, a man most skilfull of those Navigations, whom the Admirall had joyned with him by the Kings commandement.

Now it can not be expressed how many and how great tokens of a most loving minde the King at that time shewed to the Admiral, and to the County Rochfoucault, and to Theligny, and to the rest of the
chiefe Noble-men of the Religion. Many most specious tokens of the Kings love to the Admirall. First, all such things as in the former warres had been taken away in the Townes, Fermes and Castels of the Admirall and d' Andelot, the King caused to be sought out and restored. If there were any other whom the King understood to be beloved and esteemed of the Admirall, or to have attained any speciall honour in the said late warres, those he liberally benefited and rewarded. To the Admirall himselfe he commanded one day to be given an hundred thousand pounds of his own treasure in recompence of his former losses. When his brother the Cardinall Chastillion, endowed with many great and wealthy benefices, The King writes to the Duke of Savoy for savour to be shewed to them of the Religion. was departed this life, the King gave him the fruits of one whole yeare. Also the King wrote to Philibert Duke of Savoy, that he should doe him a most acceptable pleasure, if he did not only deale more gently with those that in the former wars had ayded
those of the Religion, but also would use clemencie and mildenesse toward all other that professed the same Religion within his dominions.

And for that there was old enmity betweene the Guisans and the Admirall, whereby it was to be doubted that perillous contentions would arise in the Realme of France, The Kings reconcileing the Guisans and the Admirall. The King willed it to be signified to them both in his name, that they should for his sake and the Common-weales, give over those displeasures, and hee prescribed them a certain forme of reconciliation and agreement, the same wherof the foundations had been laid almost six years before in the Towne of Molins, where the King calling to him the greatest Estates of the Realme after consultation and deliberation had upon the matter, pronounced the Admirall not guilty of the death of the Duke of Guise, wherewith he was charged by the young Duke of Guise and
his kinsmen: and so the King by the advise of his Counsel had ended that controversie.

Furrhermore, Cardinall Loraines departure to Rome, and C • rdinall Pelvey, under pretence of choosing a new Pope. the Cardinall of Loraine (who as we have sayd was the very forger of all the former warres) to take away all jelousie of new practises, was departed to Rome, and took with him his familiar friend the late created Cardinall Pelvey, one reputed a most subtil and crafty person, under pretence of going to the election of a new Pope in place of the old Pope then lately deceassed.

But there was none greater and more assured token of publique peace and quietnesse then this, A further confirmation of Peace under pretence of marriage of the kings sister to Prince Henry, son to the Queene of Navarre. that the King purposed to give his sister Margaret in marriage to the Prince Henry the sonne of the Queene of Navarre, which Prince had in the last warre defended the cause of the Religion, and been soveraigne of their armie. Which marriage the King declared, that it should be the most streight bond of civill concord,
and the most assured testimonie of his good will to those of the Religion.

Yea, and also because it was alleaged, that the said Prince Henry was restrained in conscience, so as he might not marry the Lady Margraet, being of a contrary Religion, a Catholike and given to the rites of the Romish Church, the King for answer said that he would discharge her of the Popes lawes, and notwithstanding the crying out of all his courtiers to the contrary, he permitted him, that without all ceremonies, in the porch of the great Church of Paris, the marriage should be celebrated in such a forme as the ministers of the reformed Church misliked not.

Which thing being by report and letters spread through the world, it cannot be expressed how much it made the hearts of those of the Religion assured and out of care, and how it cast out all feare and jelosies out of their minds, what a
confidence it brought them of the Kings good will toward them. Finally, how much it rejoyced forren Princes and States that favoured the same Religion? The Admiral more fully established by the Kings Letter with his owne hand and Seale. But the Admirals mind was much more stablished by a Letter which about the same time Theligny brought him with the Kings own hand and sealed, wherin was cōtained that whatsoever the Admirall should doe for the matter of the intended war of the Low-country, the King would allow and ratifie the same, as done by his own commandement. About that time Lodovick of Nassaw with the Queen of Navarre, a Lady most zealously affected to the Religion, came to the French Court. The League was made betweene King Charles & the Prince of Aurenge, and the Articles thereof put in writing. The marriage was appointed to be holden in the City of Paris. For which cause the Queene of Navarre during those few dayes repaired thither to provide things
for the solemnitie of the wedding. For the same cause the King sent to the Admirall one Caivagnes, The Kings perswading the Admiral to go to Paris, and assuring him of safety from all dangers. a man of an excellent sharpe wit, whom for the Admirals sake the King had advanced to great honour, requiring the Admirall to goe before to Paris, as well for the said preparation, as also for the matter of the warre of the Lowcountries, promising that he himselfe would within few dayes follow after him: assuring him that there was no cause for him to feare the threatnings and madde outrages of the Parisians. For, in as much as the same Towne is above all other given to superstition, and is with seditious preachings of Monkes and Friers daily enflamed to cruelty, it is hard to expresse how bitterly they hated the Admirall, and the professors of that Religion. Whereto was added a griefe of their mind conceived certaine dayes before, by reason of a certain stone-crosse gilt and built after the
manner of a spire steeple, commonly called Gastignes Crosse, which the Admirall with great earnest suit obtained of the King to be overthrowne: for he alleaged, that being erected in the middest of the rage of the Civill warre, as it were in triumph to the reproach of one of the Religion, it was a monument of civill dissention, and so a matter offensive to peace and concord.

The King wel knowing this deadly hate of the Parisians to the Admirall, To take away all feare from the Admirall, the King wrote Letters to Marcell to prevent all tumults, and so the Duke of Anjow and the Queen did the same. wrote his Letters to Marcel the Provost of the Merchants (wch is the highest dignity in Paris) with sharp threatnings if there should be raised any stirre or trouble by reason of the Admirals comming. To the same effect also the Duke of Anjow, the Kings brother, and the Queen mother, wrote to the same Marcel, and the rest of the Magistrates of Paris, so that now there seemed utterly no occasion left for the Admirall to feare or distrust.
And within few dayes after, the King sent Briquemault, a man of great vertue and estimation, to the Admirall, with the same instructions, saying, that the matter of the Low-countrey could not well be dealt in without his presence.

The Admirall perswaded by thus many meanes, and filled with good hope and courage, determined to go to Paris, where so soone as he was arrived and had been honourably and lovingly entertained of the King and his brethren, and the Queene mother, and consultation entred among them about the preparation for the Low-countrey, he declared to the King at large, how the Duke of Alva was in levying of great power, & preparing an army, and that if the King should dissemble his purpose, it would come to passe that many thereby would shew themselves slower and slacker to the enterprise, and that now were offered great meanes to doe good, which if hee let slip, hee
should not so easily recover the like againe hereafter. And therefore it was best to take the advantage of this opportunity.

A few dayes before, Lodovick of Nassaw went secretly into the frontiers of the Low-countrey, and tooke with him as partners of his journey, and privy to his counsell, three French-men of great credit with the Admirall, namely, Saucourt, la Nove, & Genlis, to whom the King had given in charge to see if they could by any means attempt and possesse any Townes bordering upon his Realme. They gathering divers other Gentlemen into their company, went speedily into the Low-countrey, the Admirall not knowing of it. Who as soone as he understood of their going thither, wrote unto them that hee much marvelled what they meant, saying that he well knew there could be no power gotten ready before forty dayes end, and that they should be well advised to do nothing rashly,
nor to overthrow with haste their devises that seemed not ripe to be executed.

The Count of Nassaw enflamed with the sight and desire of his Countrey, and fearing the mutablenesse of the King, did first at the sudden set upon Valentiennes, but being repulsed by the Spanish souldiers that were in garrison in the Castell, hee hastily departed to Montz, and took the Towne, being a place very strong by nature, and well furnished with all things necessary for the warre. Which thing being by report, and messengers spread abroad in the Low-country, and dispatched into France & Germany, both encouraged all them of the Religion with great hope, and also seemed to have now plainly and openly deciphered and disclosed the minde of the French King. Moreover, Genlis returning to Paris, when hee had made report to the King of all the matter as it had proceeded, easily obtained
of him, that by his assent he might levie certaine bandes of foot-men and horsemen of France, and carrie them to succour Montz. But by the way when he was entred into the bounds of the Low-country, having with him to the number of foure thousand foot-men, and about foure hundred horse-men, they were beset by the Duke of Alva, and the most part of them distressed: which thing was well knowne to have been wrought by the meanes of the Guisians, which by daily messages and letters, advertised the Duke of Alva of their purposes and prenaration. Which false-hood of theirs, many most affectionat to the Romish Religion, were highly offended with, because a great number addicted to the same Romish Religion were in that company.

With this losse, and with the rescue of the Towne of Valentiennes, the King seemed to be much troubled, for he feared lest his counsels
being disclosed to the Spanish King, would at length breede some cause of quarrel and war. Howbeit, when he began to remember, that a great part of his secrets was already revealed to the Duke of Alva, he oftentimes resolved to utter his mind plainly, and to make open war. But he was withdrawn from that purpose by certain men which the Admirall had long before conceived, that they would so do. Howbeit he gave the Admirall liberty to send whatso ever he thought meet to further the Prince of Aurenge his enterprise, and as great supply either of foot-men or of hors-men as he could to the armie which the Prince of Aurenge had levied in Germanie. When the Admirall for that cause had made request that he might leavie thirty troopes of horsemen, and as many ensignes of footmen, he easily obtained it.

For the entertainement of these footmen it behooved to have money,
wherefore at the request of the Admirall, the King called for his Treasurer and commanded him to deliver the Admirall so much money as the Admirall should thinke meete, and charged him, that he should not in any wise after the usuall manner of the accompts of finances, write the causes of the receit but only set it downe in this forme: This summe of money was paid to the Admiral such a day by the kings commandement, for certaine causes which the King hath commanded not to be written: and to this warrant the King subscribed with his owne hand.

Also the King wrote to Monducet, his Embassadour in the Low-countrey, to travell as earnestly as he could, for their deliverance, that were taken at the overthrow of Genlis, which commandement it is said that Monducet did most faithfully and diligently execute.

Not long before this, Ioane Queen of Navarre above mentioned,
died in the Court at Paris, of a sudden sicknesse, being about the age of forty and three yeares, where the suspition was great that she died of poyson, and her body was for that cause opened by the Physitions, there was no tokens of poyson espied. But shortly after, by the detectionof one A.P. it hath been found that she was poysoned with a venomed smell of a paire of perfumed gloves, The Qu. of Navar poysoned by the Kings Apothecary in Paris. dressed by one Renat the Kings Apothecary an Italian, who had a shop at Paris upon Saint Michaels bridge, near unto the Pallace: which could not be espied by the Physitions which did not open the head nor looked into the braine It is well knowne that the same man about certaine yeares past, for the same intent gave to Lewes Prince of Conde a poysoned Pomander, which the Prince left with one le Grosse his Surgeon, who was by little and little poysoned therewith, and so swelled, that he hardly escaped with his life.
By her death, the Kingdom came to the Prince Henry her sonne, to whom, as is above-said, the Kings sister was promised and contracted.

Things being, as it seemed, through-out all France in most peaceable estate, and the concord of all degrees well established, the day was appointed for the Marriage of the King of Navarre, which day, all they that fancied the Religion, esteemed so much the more joyfull to them, because they saw the King wonderfully bent thereunto, and all good men judged the same a most assured pledge and stablishment of civill concord; whereas, on the contrary part, the Guisans and other enemies of common quietnesse greatly abhorred the same marriage.

When the day came, the marriage was with royall pompe solemnized before the great Church of Paris, and a certaine forme of words so framed, as disagreed with the Religion of neither side, was by
the Kings commandement pronounced by the Cardinall of Burbon, the King of Navar's unkle: The solemnity of the marriage of Prince Henry and the Kings sister, with great joy on both sides. and so the matrimony was celebrated with great joy of the King and all good men, the Bride was with great train and pomp led into the Church to heare Masse, and in the meantime the Bridegroome, who misliked these Ceremonies, together with Henry Prince of Conde, sonne of Lewes, and the Admirall, and other Noble-men of the same Religion, walked without the Church-doore, waiting for the Brides returne.

While these things were in doing at Paris, Strozzi, Souldiers sent often into the Towne, under colour of Buying things necessary. who as we have said, had the charge of the Kings power at sea, hovering upon the coast of Rochell, did now and then send of his Captaines and souldiers into the Town, under colour of buying things necessary: and sometime he came thither also himselfe. The like was done at the same time in another part of France, by the horsemen of Gonzague Duke of Nivers,
neere to the Towne of la Charité, which hath a bridge over the River of Loyre, and remained till that time in the power of those of the Religion, by reason of the great number of them there inhabiting. This troop was of those horse-men which the King hath accustomed to keepe in ordinary wages in every Country, whereof the most part were Italians, country-men to their Captain Lewes Gonzague, to whom the Queene mother had given the daughter and heire of the Duke of Nivers in marriage. They requested of the Townes-men, The Governour of Lions takes a view of all the Protestants, and writ them in a book, which was after called the bloudy booke. that they might make their Muster within the Towne, saying that they had received warrant from the King so to doe, and shewed the Kings Letters therefore. At Lions the Governour of the Town, commanded a view to be taken of all those that professed the Religion, and their names to be written in a book and brought unto him: which book shortly after, according to the successe,
was called the bloudy booke.

After themarriage ended at Paris, which was the time that the Admirall had appointed to returne to his owne house, he moved the King concerning his departure. But so great was the preparatiō of Playes, so great was the magnificence of banquets and shewes, and the King so earnestly bent to those matters, that he had no leasure, not only for waighty affaires, but also not so much as to take his naturall sleepe. For in the French Court, Dancings, Maskings, Stage-playes (wherein the King exceedingly delighted) are commonly used in the night-time: and so the time that is fittest for counsel and matters of governance, is by reason of nightly riotous sittings up, of necessity consumed in sleepe. So great also is the familiarity of men and the women of the Queen mothers traine, and so great liberty of sporting, entertainment and talking together, as to forren Nations may seeme incredible, and
be thought of all honest persons a matter not very convenient for preservation of noble young Ladies chastitie. Moreover, if there come any pandor or bawde out of Italie, or any Scholemaster of shamefull and filthy lust, he winneth in short time marvellous favour and credit. And such a multitude is there begunne to be of Italians, commonly throughout all France, specially in the court, since the administration of the Realme was commited to the Queene mother, that many doe commonly call it France-Italian, and some terme it a Colonie, and some a common sincke of Italie.

These madnesses of the Court, The Admirall desiring to depart from Paris, but was stayed, partly because he could not have accesse to the King, who was excessively inten • ive on his sports and banquet, partly because he was entreated to stay and deliver Petitions to the King in the cause of the Churches and other reasons. were the cause that the Admirall could not have accesse to the Kings speech, nor entrance to deale in waighty matters. But when they that were sent from the reformed Churches to complaine of injuries commonly done to those of the Religion, understood of the Admirals purpose to depart, they
did with all speed deliver to him their bookes and petitions, and besought him, not to depart from the Court till he had dealt in the cause of the Churches, and delivered their petitions to the King and his Councell. For this cause the Admirall resolved to deferre his going for a while, till he might treat with the Kings Councell concerning those requests: for the King had promised him that he would shortly entend those matters, and be present with the Councel himselfe.

Besides this delay, there was another matter that stayed him. There was owing to the Rutters of Germanie, which had served on the part of the Religion in the last war, great summes of money for their wages, in which matter the Admirall travelled with incredible earnestnesse and care.

Concerning all these affaires, The Admirals accesse to the King, and treats with him. the Admiral (as he determined before) having accesse and opportunitie for that purpose, moved the
Kings privy Councell the 22. day of August, which was the fifth day after the King of Navar's marriage, and spent much time in that treaty. The Admirall returning home from the Councell, was treacherously shot out at a window, and sorely wounded. About noone, when he was in returning home from the Councell, with a great company of Noblemen and Gentlemen, behold, a Harquebuzier out of a window of a house neare adjoyning, shot the Admirall with two bullets of lead thorow both the armes. When the Admirall felt himselfe wounded, nothing at all amazed, but with the same countenance that he was accustomed, he said, thorow yonder window it was done: go see who are in the house. What māner of trechery is this? Then he sent a certain Gentleman of his company to the King to declare it unto him. The King at that time was playing at Tennise with the Duke of Guise. The King seemingly much moved at the Admirals hurt. As soone as he heard of the Admirals hurt, he was marvellously moved, as it seemed, and threw away his racket that he played with
on the ground, and taking with him his brother in law, the King of Navarre, hee retired into his Castle.

The Gentlemen that were with the Admirall brake into the house from whence he received his hurt, there they found only one woman, the keeper of the house, and shortly after also a boy, his lackey that had done • he deed, and therewithall they found the harquebuze lying upon the table in that chamber from whence the noyse was heard: him that shot they found not, Hee that shot the Admirall flyes, having fresh horses ready prepared in divers places. for he in great haste was runne away out at the back-gate, and getting on horse-back, which he had waiting for him ready sadled at the doore, he rode a great pace to Saint Anthonies gate, where he had a fresh horse tarying for him, if need were, and another at Marcelles gate. Then by the kings commandement a great number rode out in poste into all parts to pursue him: The King sends posts after him. but for that he was slipped into by-wayes,
and received into a certaine Castle, they could not overtake him.

At the sute of the King of Navarre, The King gives commission to three of the Parliament of Paris to examine the bustnesse. and the Prince of Conde and other, the King by and by gave commssion for enquirie to be made of the matter, and committed the examining thereof to three chosen persons of the Parliament of Paris, Thuan and Morsant and Viol a couuseller.

First it was found that the same house belonged to a Priest, a Canon of Saint Germaine, whose name is Villemure, which had been the Duke of Guises schole-master in his youth, The businesse examined. and still continued a retayner toward him. Then the woman which we said was found in the house, being taken and brought before them, confessed that a few dayes before, there came to her one Chally sometime a Mr. de Hostel of the Duke of Guises house, and now of the Kings court, and commanded her to make much of the man that had done this deede,
and to lodge him in the same bed and chamber where Villemure was wont to lie, for that he was his friend and very familiar acquaintance, and that Villemure would be very glad of it. The name of him that shot was very diligently kept secret. Some say it was Manrevet, which in the third civill warre traiterously slew his captaine Monsieur de Movy, a most valiant and noble gentleman, and straightway fled into the enemies campe. Some say it was Bondot, one of the archers of the Kings guard. When the womans confession was brought to the King, he immediatly called Monsieur de Nance, captaine of his guard, and commanded him to apprehend Challey and bring him to him. Challey assoone as hee heard the stroke of the peece, fled into the Kings castle called the Louure, & hid him in the Duke of Guises chamber, from whence he conveyed himself away assoone as he had heard of
the Kings commandement. When de Nance was informed of his departure, he answered that Challey was a gentleman of good worship, and there was no doubt but if neede were he would appeare before the King and the Magistrates.

While these things were doing, The Admirall being in danger of his life, sends for the King. and the Admirals wound in dressing, Theligny went by his comandement to the King, and most humbly besought him in the name of his father in law, that his Majestie would vouchsafe to come unto him for that his life seemed to be in perill, and that he had certaine things to say, greatly importing to the Kings safety, which he well knew that none in his Realme durst declare to his Majestie. The King curteously answered that he would willingly go to him, and within a little while after he set forward. The Queen mother went with him and the Duke of Anjow, the Duke of Mondensier, a most affectionate
subject to the Church of Rome, The King goes to the Admirall with the Queene mother & others. the County de Rhetz, the Queen mothers great familiar, Chavigny and Entragny, which afterward were chiefe ringleaders in the butchery of Paris.

When the King had lovingly saluted the Admirall as he was wont to do, The Kings loving salutation of the Admirall. and had gently asked him some questions concerning his hurt and the estate of his health, and the Admirall had answered with such a milde and quiet countenance, that all they that were present wondered at his temperance and patience, the King being much moved (as it seem'd) said, The hurt, The Kings deepe oath severely to revenge the Admirals hurt. my Admirall, is done to thee, but the dishonour to me: but (swearing a great oath) saith he, I sweare I will so severely revenge both the hurt and the dishonour, that it shall never be forgotten. He asked him also how he liked of the Judges that he had chosen, to whom he had given commission for examining the matter. The Admirall answered
that he could not but very well like of those that his Majestie had allowed of, yet he besought him if he thought it good, that Cavagnes might be called to counsell with them, albeit that it was no hard matter to find out, for it was no doubt (said he) that this good turne was done him by the Duke of Guise, the revenge whereof he referred to God. The Admirall entreats the King to enquire straitly into the fact. And the Kings kind Answer. This only he most heartily and humbly besought of his royall Majestie, that the fact might be dulie enquired into. The King answered that he would take earnest care of it, and revenge that injurie with no lesse severity than if it had been done to himselfe. Then the Kings brethren and their mother withdrawing themselves a while, The Admirall faithfully advises the King to beware of treasons against himselfe. the Admirall as it was afterward knowne by his owne report, began to advise the King to have in memorie those things that he had oft told him of the dangerous intentions of certaine persons and he told him, that though he himselfe
had received a great wound, yet there was no lesse hanging over the Kings head: and that long ago there was treason in practizing against his life, which if he would do wisely he should avoyd betimes. Further he said, that though so soone as God should take him to himselfe out of this life, he doubted not but that his fame should be brought into sundry slanders by envious persons, and such as ought him evill will by reason of the late wars, neverthelesse he had oftentimes disclosed unto the King the authors of the dissentions, and opened the causes thereof, and that God was his witnesse of his most faithfull heart to the King and the Commonweale, and that he had never holden any thing dearer then his countrey and the publique safetie.

The King after such answer made hereunto as hee thought best, spake aloud, and heartily entreated the Admirall to suffer himselfe to be removed into his castell of the
Louure, The King under pretence of sedition feared, desires the Admirall to be removed into his Castle of Louure. for that he thought some perill, lest there should arise some sedition among the commons already in disorder, or any stirre in that madde and troublesome Citie. Wherto this speech of the King tended could not then be vnderstood. For though the commonalty of Paris hath ever been accompted the most foolish and madde of al other, yet is it ever most easily appeased, not onely with the comming and presence of the King, but also with the very sound of his name. The Admiral most humbly and largely thanked the King, and made his excuse upon the counsell of the Phisicians, The Admirall, by the advise of the Physitians, excuses his desire not to remove. which feared that shaking would encrease his paine, and therefore had taken order that he should not be stir'd out of his place. Then the Count de Rhetz turning to certaine Gentle-men of the Admirals friends, said, I would the Admirall would follow the Kings counsell, for it is to be feared that some such stir may arise in the
Towne, as the King shall not easily be able to appease. Which speech being vnttered, although no man did yet suspect whereto that advise tended, The Admirall requests a Guard for his safety, to which the King willingly yeelds. yet the Admirall and his friends thought it good to request of the King to assigne unto him certain of the souldiers of the Guard for his safetie. The King answered that he very well liked of that devise, &p that he was fully determined to provide as wel for the Admirals safetie as for his owne, The Kings high expressions of love and praise to the Admirall. and that he would preserve the Admirall as the ball of his eye, and that he had in admiration the constancie and fortitude of the man, and that he never before that time beleeved that there could be so great valiantnesse of courage in any mortall person.

Therewith the Duke of Anjow the kings brother cōmanded Cossin Captaine of the Kings Guard, The Admirals Guard placed. to place a certaine band of Souldiers to ward before the Admirals gate. There could hardly a man
be found more hatefull against the Admirals part, nor more affected to the Guisians then this Cossin, which the successe plainly proved, as hereafter shall apeare. The Duke of Anjow causes the Admirals friends to be placed in those lodgings neer about him, under pretence of the Admirals safeguard, and others to be remooved from their lodgings, which was a most devillish plot to bring in the Protestants out of the suburbs, from whence they might perhaps have escaped into one narrow street within the wals, that they could not possible avoyd their plotted destruction. The Duke of Anjow further added, that he thought it should be good for the Admirall, if moe of his friends and familiars that lodged in the fauxburges did drawe nearer about him: and forthwith he commanded the Kings harbingers to warn those to whom they had before assigned lodgings in that street, to remove from thence, and to place the Admirals friends in their roomes. Which counsell was such, as none could possibly be devised more fit for those things that followed. For those which might have by flight escaped out of the suburbs were now holden fast enough, being enclosed not only within the wals of
the Towne, but also within the compasse of one narrow street. The next day after, The names of the Protestants strictly taken, with the place of every of their lodgings. the Under-masters of the streets, commonly called Quarter-men, surveyed all the victualling houses and Innes, from house to house, and all the names of those of the Religion, together with the place of every of their lodgings they put in bookes, and with speed delivered over the same bookes to those of whom they had received that command.

In the afternoon, the Queen mother lead out the King, the Duke of Anjow, Gonzague, Tavaignes, the County de Rhetz, called Gondin, into her Gardens called Tegliers. This place, because it was somwhat farre from resort, she thought most fit for this their last consultation. There she shewed them, how those whom they had long been in wait for, were now sure in hold, and the Admirall lay in his bed maimed of both his armes and could not stirre, the King of Navarre
and the Prince of Conde were fast lodged in the Castle, The King and the Queene consults about their last most bloudy and devillish defigne. the gates were kept shut all night, and watches placed, so as they were so snared that they could no way escape, and the Captains thus taken, it was not to be feared that any of the Religion would from thenceforth stir any more. Now was a notable opportunity (said she) offered to dispatch the matter. For all the chiefe Captaines were fast closed up in Paris, and the rest in other Towns were all unarmed and unprepared, and that there were scarcely to be found ten enemies to a thousand Catholikes: that the Parisians were in armour and were able to make threescore thousand chosen fighting men, and that within the space of one houre all the enimies may be slayne, and the whole name and race of those wicked men be vtterly rooted out. On the other side (saith she) if the King do not take the advantage of the fitnesse of this time, it is no doubt but
that if the Admirall recover his health, all France wil shortly be on fire with the fourth civill war.

The Queenes opinion was allowed. Howbeit it was thought best, partly for his age, and partly for the affinities sake, that the King of Navarres life should be saved. As for the Prince of Conde, it was doubted whether it were best to spare him for his age, or to put him to death for hatred of his fathers name. The King and the Queene consults to put this designe into execution, and committed the doing of it to the Duke of Guise. But herein the opinion of Gonzague took place, that he should with feare of death and torment, be drawne from the Religion. So that counsell brake up, with appoyntment that the matter should be put in execution the next night early afore day, and that the ordering and doing of all should be commited to the Duke of Guise.

The Admirall being enformed of stirre and noyse of armour, and threatnings heard every where throughout the towne, and preparation of many things pertaining to
tumult, The King sends to the Admiral, to take away all suspition of feare. sent word thereof to the King: who answered, that there was no cause for the Admirall to feare, for all was done by his command and not every where, but in certaine places, & that there were certaine appointed by him to be in armor, lest the people should rise and make any stir in the Towne.

When the Duke of Guise thought all things readie enough, The Duke of Guise causeth the Officers to be assembled to declare the Kings minde, which was to destroy al the Protestants, which hee now stiles Rebels, notwithstanding his former acts of favour and Pacification. he called to him the abovesaid Marcell, and charged him that he should a little after midnight assemble together the Masters of the streets whom they call Diziners into the Towne house, for he had certaine strange and speciall matters in charge from the King, which his pleasure was to have declared unto them. They all assembled betimes, Carron the new Provost of Merchants, guarded with certaine Guisians, and among the rest Entragne and Pnygallart, made the declaration: He said that the Kings meaning was to destroy all the Rebels which
had in these late yeares borne armes against his Majestie, and to root out the race of those wicked men, it was now very fitly happened that the Chieftaines and ringleaders of them were fast enclosed within the walles of the Towne, as in a prison, and that the same night they should first begin with them, and afterward for the rest as soone as possibly might be, throughout all parts of the Realme the King would take order: and the token to set upon them, should be given, not with a trumpet, Tokens to distinguish who was to bee slaine and who not. but with tocksein or ringing of the great bell of the Pallace, which they knew to be accustomed only in great cases: and the mark for them to be known from other, should be a white linnen cloath hanged about their left arme, and a white crosse pinned upon their caps. In the meane time the Duke of Guise made privie thereunto the captains of the Kings guard, both Gascoignes, Frenchmen, and Switzers, & bad them be ready
to go to it with good courage. Shortly after, the Duke of Guise and the bastard sonne of king Henry, commonly called the Chevalier, with a great band of armed men following them, went to the Admirals house, which Cossin kept besieged with Harquebuziers, placed in order on both sides of the street.

The Admirall advertised of the stirre and the noise of the armour, although hee had scarcely ten persons in his house able to beare harnesse, and in his chamber only two Surgeons, one Preacher, and one or two servitors, yet could not be made afraid, trusting (as he oft rehearsed) upon the Kings good will toward him, approved by so many and so great meanes of assurance, having also confidence that the Commonalty of Paris if they once understood the king to mislike of their mad fury, how much soever they were in outrage, yet so soon as they saw Cossin warding the gate, they would be appeased. He repeated
also the Oath for keeping of the Peace, The Admiralls confidence being hardly brought to feare, notwith standing all these stirs considering. The divers ratifications of peace by the King, his Treaties, Oaths so often, and upon record, Leagues, Mariages, publique Faith. The sacred respect of the Law of Nations, &c. so oft openly sworne by the King and his brethren, and their Mother, and entred in publique records, the league lately made with the Queene of England for the same cause, the Articles of treatie covenanted with the Prince of Aurenge, the Kings faith given to the Princes of Germany, some Townes attempted and some taken in the Low-countrey by the Kings commandement, the marriage of the Kings Sister solemnized but six dayes before, which it was not like that he would suffer to bee defiled with bloud: finally the judgement of forren nations & of posterity, shame, and the honour and constancie of a Prince, publique Faith, and the sa / cred respect of the law of Nations; all which it seemed monstrous and incredible that the king could assent to be stained with so outragious a cruell deed.

Cossin, when he saw the Noble / men draw neare, knocked at the
gate, which as is above-said, he was commanded by the Duke of Anjow to keepe. Whereupon many applyed the old proverbe, A goodly guard to make the Wolfe keeker of the sheepe.
Cossin, the Captain of the Guard before the Admiralsgate, enters the gate, slew all within the porch at the entry. When hee was entred without (in a manner) any difficulty, he carryed in with him a great company of armed men, and after those followed the great Lords. Such as Cossin found at the entry of and within the porch of the house, he slew with a Partisan that he had in his hand. Which when the Admirall understood, he caused those that were about him to lift him out of his bed, and casting on a night-gowne upon him, he rose upright on his feet, he bade his friends and servants to flee and make shift for themselves, and to take no more care for him, for he said that he was ready with most willing heart to render into the hands of God, now calling for it againe, the spirit that hee had lent him to use for a time: and said that this violent
cruelty was prepared not so much for his destruction, The Admirall expects now, and prepares to dye. as for the dishonouring of Christ and the tormenting of so many Churches, the defence of which Churches he had at the petition of all godly men with his many dangers and calamities sustained.

In the meane time there came up the staires into the upper part of the house, They break into the Admirals chamber. one Benvese a Germaine, brought up in the house of the Duke of Guise, and to whom it is saide, that the Cardinall of Loraine had given one of his bastard daughters in marriage: and with him came Cossin the Gascoin, Attin a Picarde a retainer and familiar of the Duke d'Aumal, one that a few yeares before sought to murther d'Andelot by treason, and also one Hamfort an Avernois, all weaponed with swords and targets, and armed with shirts of maile.

When they were broken into the Admirals chamber, Benvese came to him, and bending his drawn
sword upon him, said, Art not thou the Admirall? he with a quiet and constant countenance, (as we have since understood by themselves) answered, I am so called. And then seeing the sword drawn upon him, hee said, young man, consider my age and the weak case that I am now in. One blaspheming God, runs his sword into the Admirall, and strikes him. Another shootes him. But the fellow, after blaspheming God, first thrust his sword into the Admirals brest, and then also strucke him upon the head, and Attin shot him thorow the brest with a pistol. When the Admiral was with this wound not yet throughly dead, Benvese gave him the third wound upon the thigh, and so he fell downe for dead. They wound him the third time, so he falls downe dead. When the Duke of Guise, which stayed in the court with the other noble men, heard this, he cried out alowd, hast thou done Benvese? he answered, I have done. Then said the Duke of Guise, our Chevelier (meaning King Henries bastard abovesaid) unlesse hee see it with his eyes, will not beleeve it
throw him downe at the window. Then Benvese with the help of his fellowes tooke up the Admirals body and threw it downe thorow the window. At the Duke of Guises command they throw him out at a window. When by reason of the wound in his head, and his face covered with blood they could not well discerne him, The Duke of Guise gratulates their happy beginning: commanding to go on, crying out This is the Kings command, his will, his pleasure. the Duke of Guise kneeled downe on the ground and wiped him with a napkin and said, now I know him, it is he. And therewithall going out at the gate with the rest of the Lords, he cred out to the multitude armour, saying my companions we have had good lucky beginning: now let us go forward to the rest, for it is the Kings commandement: which words hee did oft repeate alowd, saying, Thus the King commandeth: This is the Kings will, this is his pleasure. And then he commanded the token to be given by ringing tocksein with the great bell of the pallace, and alarme to be raised, and he caused it to be published, that the conspiratours
were in armour and about to kill the King. Then a certain Italian of Gonzagues band, One cuts off his head, other his hands, other his secret parts, they drag him thorow the streets, hangs him by the feet. cut off the Admirals head, and sent it preserved with spices to Rome to the Pope and the Cardinall of Loraine. Other cut off his hands, and other his secret parts. Then the common labourers and rascals three daies together dragged the dead body thus mangled and berayed with blood and filth, thorow the streets, and afterward drew it out of the towne to the common gallowes, and hanged it up with a rope by the feet. The Admirals most cruel and treacherous death, with all about him, the end and issue of all the Kings grace and favour towards him.

In the meane time, those of the noble mens bands brake into all the chambers of the Admirals house, and such as they found either in their beds, or hidden, they mangled them with many wounds, and so slaughtered them. Of that number were two young children, pages, of honourable birth. There was also the Counte Rochfoucault, which for the excellent pleasentnesse
of his wit, and for his valiantnesse was highly beloved of King Henry, and so seemed for the same cause also to be beloved of the King. Him was de Nance abovesaid commanded to kill, but he refusing it for their old accquaintance and familiarity: one Laberge an Avernois offered himselfe to the King to do it, but with this condition, that the King should give him the captaineship of horse-men which Count Rochfoucault had. Counte Rochfoucault slain. Theligny the Admirals son in law slaine. There was also slayne Theligny the Admirals son in law, a young man of singular towardnesse both of wit and courage, to whom the King these many yeares had both in words and countenance made shew of so great good will, as that no man was thought to be more highly in his favor. He crying out, that it was now grievious to him to live, for that he had ever commended to his father in law the faithfulnesse of the King, refused not the death offered him. And many other most
flourishing young noble men and gentlemen were every where butcherly murthered in that street. Many gallant Nobles and Gentlemen murthered in the streets. Then the noble mens bands, and Cossins souldiers went ransacking from house to house: and the Admirals house and al the other houses were all sacked and spoyled, The sackings and spoilings by the souldiers. even in like manner as is used to be done by souldiers greedy of prey in a Towne taken by assault: and many by this robbery, were of beggers suddenly become rich men. For the Duke of Guise, the Duke of Monpensier, the Chevalier King Henries bastard, Gonzague, Tavaignes, and the other great Lords, did with reward of the spoyle and bootie encourage the multitude to the slaughter, and cried out aloud that this was the Kings will. They cry out still This is the Kings wil. So all the rest of the day from morning to evening, the rascall multitude, encouraged by spoyle and robberie, ran with their bloudy swords raging thorowout al the Towne: they spared not the aged, nor women,
nor the very babes: The streets strewed with murthered bodies. In joy and triumph they threw the slayne bodies out at the windowes, so as there was not in manner any one street or lane, that seemed not strewed with murthered car cases.

While these things were thus a doing in the Towne, the King of Navarre and the Prince of Conde, whom the King had lodged in his owne castle of the Louure, were by the Kings commandement sent for and conveyed unto him. The King of Navar, and Prince of Conde their company, servitours, friends, hewed in pieces and slaine, themselves sent for to the King. But their company, their servitours of their chamber, their friends retaining to them, their schole-masters, and those that had the bringing up of them, crying out alowd to the Kings fidelity for succour, were thrust out of the chambers, and by the Kings guard of Switzers hewed in pieces and slaughtered in the Kings owne sight. But of that number of persons slayne, no mans case was so much lamented of many, as Monsieur de Pilles, in whom it is hard to expresse whether there
were more godly zeale in Religion, or prowesse in warre. Whereby having in the late yeares, specially by the defence of the Towne of Saint Iohn d' Angeli, which the King then besieged, gotten great honour of Chevalry, he was thought very well beloved and highly esteemed of the King. Him and Leranne the son of Odou, by the French Kings commandement (which was not then understood whereto ittended) the King of Navar had staied in a wardrob adjoyning to his own chamber, and caused them to lodge there all night. A little afore day, hearing of the running of men, and noise of armour, and cryes and killings, they rose in hast, & immediatly de Nance whom we have before spoken of, came to them, and cōmanded them in the Kings name to come downe into the Court, and to leave their weapons behind them, and lastly to depart out of the castle. When de Pilles saw himselfe thrust out
among the multitude of the murthering souldiers,
Monsieur de Pilles seemingly much esteemed of the King, treacherously slaine. He detests the Kings traytero is infidelity in the Kings hearing. and beheld the bodies of them that were slaine; he cryed out with a very lowd voyce, that the King might well heare him, protesting upon the Kings fidelity, and detesting his trayterous infidelity, and therwith he took off a rich cloak which he wore, and gave it to one of his acquaintance, saying, take here this token of Pilles, and hereafter remember Pilles most unworthily and shamefuly slaine. Oh my good Monsieur de Pilles, said the other, I am none of them: I thanke you for your cloake, but I will not receive it with that condition, and so refused to take the cloake: and immediately de Pilles was thrust thorow by one of the Guard with a Partisan, and died. And this end had this most valiant and Noble Gentleman. And then his body was throwne into the quarrey with the rest; which when they that passed by did behold, the souldiers cryed out, there they
be that made assault upon us, and would have killed the King. Leranne being thrust thorow with a sword, escaped and ran into the Queen of Navarres chamber, and was by her kept and preserved from the violence of those that pursued him. Shortly after, she obtained his pardon of her brother, and committing him to her owne Physitians, restored him both to life and health.

While things were in doing at Paris, Strozzi, which (as we have aforesaid) was come with all his power to Rochel, sent a great number of his souldiers into the Town, under colour of a banket to be made to his friends in the castell called la Chein, Civell treason under pretence of a banquet. but by reason of the jealousie and watches of the townes men, by whom hee saw his treason was espied, he went away without his purpose. But they of la Charity, which as we have before shewed, were trapped by the Italian horsemen, taking lesse heed to the safe
keeping of their Towne, were a little before night surprized, and within few daies after put to the sword.

The next day following, where any that had hidden themselves in corners at Paris could be found out the slaughter was renewed: The slaughter renewed the next day. also common labourers and porters, and other of the most rascals of the people and desperate villaines, They strip the dead bodies and threw them into the river Seane. to have the spoyle of their clothes, stripped the dead bodies stark naked and threw them into the river of Seane. The profit of all the robberies and spoyles came all for the most part to the hands of these laborers and the souldiers, and to the Kings treasure came very little or nothing. The only gaine that came to him, was that which might be made of the vacations (as they terme them) of offices and of places of Magistrates, Captaines and other rooms of charge, wherof yet he gave a great part freely away to divers of the Court. For the Admirals office he gave to Marques d'Villars,
the Chancellorship of Navarre, The Admirals Office, & other Offices disposed of. after the murther of Francourt, he by and by gave to Henry Memne de Malassise, which had been the truceman and messenger in the Treaty of the last peace: the Office of the Master of the Finances after the slaughter of Prunes he gave to Villequier, the Office of President des aides, when Plateau was slaine he gave to de Nully: the other Offices hee sold, as his manner is, to such as gave ready mony for them. For it hath been the custome now lately of certaine Kings of France (such as among forren Nations hath not been heard of) to put to sale all the profits, rights, and benefits of of the Crown, Offices sold for ready money. and to keep an open market for money, of all judiciall Offices, and of the Roomes belonging to his Treasure and Fiances, according to a rate of price set upon every one of them: Vendere jure potest, • anerat ille prius. and there is not in manner one in all France, that doth not openly justifie that hee bought his Office for ready money,
and that no man ought to marvell if he desire to fill up the empty hole of his stock againe. And therefore Justice is thorow all France usually bought for money, and though there be never so many murthers committed, yet is there no Processe awarded to enquire thereof, till present coyne be payd to the rake-hels and scribes.

This butcherly slaughter of Paris thus performed, and foure hundred houses (as is above-said) sacked, immediately messengers were sent in post into all parts of the Realme, Letters in the Kings name to all other Cities, to follow the example of Paris in this bloudy Massacre. with oft shifting their horses for haste, to command all other Cities in the Kings name to follow the example of Paris, and to cause to be killed as many as they had among them of the reformed Religion.

These commandements it is wonderful to tel how readily and cheerfully the greatest part of the Cities of France did obey and execute. But the King, fearing (as it was likely) the dishonour of false treachery
