and wine under the said formes (are in the Masse by the words wch serve for consecration, said and pronounced by the Priest) transubstantiated and transformed into the substance of the said body & bloud of Jesus Christ. Notwithstanding, that the qualities and accidents remaine in the said formes after the said consecration, & that the Masse is holesome and profitable as well for the quick as the dead. I acknowledge and confesse the concomitance, that is to say, that in receiving the body of Jesus Christ under the forme of bread alone, I likewise receive the bloud of Jesus Christ. I confesse that Prayer and intercession of Saints for the quicke and the dead is holy, good and healthful for Christians, and is not contrary (for any respect) to the glory of God. That prayers made in the Church for the faithfull which are dead, do profit them for the remission of their sinnes, and lessening of their paines incurred for the same. That
there is a Purgatory where the souls abiding are succoured by the prayers of the faithfull. I confesse that we must honour and call upon the Saints which reigne with Jesus Christ, and that they make intercession for us to God, and that their Relikes are to be worshipped. That the Commandements and Traditions of the Catholique, Apostolique and Romish Church, as well they which pertaine to the forme & ceremonies of divine Service, and to assist the same, which I think be to draw Christian people to piety and turning to their God, as fasting, abstaining from meats, observation of Holy-dayes, and Ecclesiasticall policie, according to the tradition of the Apostles and holy Fathers, continued since the Primitive Church till this time, & afterwards brought into the Church by the ordinances of Councels received in the same of long and ancient time, or of late, be good and holy, to the which I will and ought to obey, as prescribed and
appointed by the Holy Ghost, the Author and director of that which serveth for the keeping of Christian Religion, and of the Catholique Apostolique and Roman Church. I Beleeve also and accept all the articles of originall sin, and of Justification. I affirme assuredly, that we ought to have and keep the Images of Jesus Christ, of his holy Mother, and all other Saints, and do honour and reverence unto them. I confesse the power of Indulgence and Pardons to be left in the Church by Jesus Christ, and the use of them to be very healthfull, as also I acknowledge and confesse the Church of Rome to be the Mother and chiefe of all Churches, and conducted by the Holy Ghost: and that other pretended particular inspirations against the same, come of the suggestion of the Devill, the Prince of dissention, which would separate the union of the mysticall Body of the Saviour of the world. Finally, I promise straightly to keep all that
was ordained at the last Generall Councell of Trent, and promise to God and you, never more to depart from the Catholique, Apostolique, and Roman Church: and if I do (which God forbid) I submit my selfe to the penalties of the Canons of the said Church, made, ordained, and appointed against them which fall back into Apostasie. The which Abjuration and Confession I have subscribed.

div.head: THE KINGS LETTER to M. de Guise, and other Lieutenants and Governours of his Provinces, by the which hee wholly abolisheth and subverteth all the Edicts of Pacification, and willeth that only the Romish Religion should take place in his Realme.
div.p:
THE King knowing that the Declaration which hee made upon the occasion which lately chanced in the City of Paris, the remembrances
and instructions of his will which he sent round about to all Governours of his Provinces, and Lieutenants generall therein, and particular letters to the Seneshals, and his Courts of Parliament, and other Officers and Ministers of Justice, cannot hitherto stay the course of murthers and robberies done in the most part of the Cities of this Realme, to his Majesties great displeasure: hath advised for a more singular remedy, to send all the said Governours into every of their charges and governments, assuring himselfe, that according to the quality and power which they have of his Majesty, they can well follow and observe his intent, the which more fully to declare, his Majesty hath caused his Letters Patents to be dispatched, which shall be delivered them. Besides the contents whereof M. de Guise the Governour, and Lieutenant generall for his Majesty in Champaigne and Brye, shall call before him the Gentlemen of the new Religion abiding within his government,
and shall tell them that the Kings will and intent is to preserve them, their wives, children and families, and to maintain them in possession of their goods, so that on their part they live quietly, and render to his Majesty obedience and fidelity as they ought: in which doing the King also will defend them, that they shall not be molestea or troubled by way of Justice, or otherwise in their persons and goods, by reason of things done during the troubles, and before the Edict of Pacification of August, 1570. And afterwards hee shall lovingly admonish them to continue no longer in the Error of the new Opinions, and to returne to the Catholike Religion, reconciling themselves to the Catholique Romish Church, under the doctrine and obedience whereof, the King his predecessours and their subjects have alwayes holily lived, and this Realme hath been carefully conducted and maintained: Shewing to them the mischiefes and calamities which have happened in
this Realme, since these new opinions have entred into mens spirits: How many murders have been caused by such which have fallen from the right way holden by their Ancestors. First, they made them separate themselves from the Church, then from their next of kindred, and also to be estranged from the service of their King, as a man may see since his reigne. And although the authors and heads of that side, would have covered their doings under the title of Religion and conscience: yet their deeds and workes have shewen well enough that the name of Religion was but a vizzard to cover their drifts and disobedience, and under that pretence to assemble and suborn people, and to make and compell them to sweare in the cause under the title of disobedience, and by such wayes to turne them from the naturall affection which they owe to the King, and consequently from his obedience; it being notorious, that what commandement soever the King could
make to them of the new Religion, they have not since his reigne obeyed him otherwise than pleased their heads. And contrariwise, when their said heads commanded them to arise and take to their weapons, to set upon Cities, to burne Churches, to sack and pill, to trouble the Realme, and fill it with bloud and fire, they which went so astray to follow them, forgot all trust and duty of good subjects, to execute and obey their commandements. Which things if the Gentlemen will well consider, they shall easily judge how unhappy and miserable their condition shall be, if they continue longer therein. For they may well thinke of themselves, that the King being taught by experience of so great a danger, from the which it hath pleased God to preserve him and his Estate, and having proved the mischiefes and calamities which this Realm hath suffred by the enterprise of the heads of this cause, their adherents and complices, that he will never willingly be served with any
Gentlemen of his subjects that be of any other Religion than the Catholique, in the which also the King, following his predecessors, will live and die. He willeth also to take away all mistrust amongst his subjects, and to quench the rising of discords and seditions, that all they of whom he is served in honourable places, and specially the Gentlemen which desire to be accompted his good and lawfull subjects, and would obtaine his favour, and be employed in charges of his service, according to their degrees and qualities, doe make profession here-after to live in the same Religion that he doth: having tryed that discords and civill warres will not cease in a State where there be many Religions, and that it is not possible for a king to maintain in his Realme diversities in Religion, but that hee shal lose the good wil & benevolēce of his subjects, yea, and they which are of a contrary Religion to his, desire nothing in their heart more than the change of the King and of his
Estate. For the reason above-said, the Duke of Guise, to bring the matter to this passe, shall take paines to perswade the Nobility and others infected with the said new Opinion, to returne of themselves, and of their owne free-will to the Catholique Religion, and to abjure and renounce the New, without any more expresse commandement from the King. For howsoever it be, his Majesty is resolved to make his subjects live in his Religion, and never to suffer whatsoever may betide, that there shall bee any other forme or exercise of Religion in his Realm then the Catholique; The said Duke of Guise shall communicate with the principal Officers and Magistrates, having the principall charge and administration of Justice in Cities of his government, his Majesties declaration, to the intent they should know his mind, and the good end whereunto he tendeth for the uniting and quietnesse of his subjects, to the intent the said M. de Guise, and the said
Officers and Magistrates, should with one concord, intelligence and correspondence proceed to the effect above-said, so that fruit and quietnesse may thereof ensue, such as his Majesty desireth, not only for himselfe, but for the whole Realme. The Baylifes and Stewards which are not in Religion accordingly qualified, shall within one moneth resigne their Offices to Gentlemen capable, and of the quality required by the Edict, which may keepe and exercise the same. And to the intent this should be done, his Majesty doth now presently declare them deprived after the said month, if they do not then resigne, that they shall have no occasion or colour of excuse to delay their resignations, and yet permitteth them in the mean while to resigne without any fine paying. All Baylifes and Stewards shall be resident at their offices upon paine of losse of the same, and if they cannot so be, then they shall be bound to resigne. All Archbishops and Bishops shall likewise be resident
in their Dioces and such as for age & other indisposition of person cannot preach the Word of God, nor edifie the people, and do other functions appertaining to their charge and dignity, shall be bound to take a conductor to comfort them, and to employ themselves to the duty of their charge. To the which Conductor they shall appoint an honest and reasonable pension according to the fruits and revenue of their living. Also Parsons and Vicars shall be resident at their Benefices, or else shall be admonished to resigne them to such as will be resident, and do their duty. Archbishops and Bishops shall take information of them which hold Abbeyes, Priories, and other Benefices in their Diocesse, of what quality soever they are, and how they do their duty in the administration of them, where upon they shall make processe by word unto the Governours, which shall send them to the King to provide therein as reason shall move him. They shall compell the Curates
actually to abide at the places of their Benefices, or else shall appoint other in their steads according to the disposition of the Cannons.

closer.dateline: At Paris the third of November, 1572.

div.head: LETTERS OF M. DE Gordes, the Kings Lieutenant in Daulphine, to certaine of the Religion in his Government, wherby he exhorteth them to come backe againe to the Religion of Rome; and how the King is determined to suffer none other.

p.hi:
SIr, I am sufficiently advertised of your behaviour, but you should remember what advertisements I have before sent you to returne to the Catholique Religion of your selfe, which is the best hold and stay that you can choose for your preservation and health putting from you all those which perswade you to the contrary, who would abide to see any commotion or disorder, rather than abate
any point of their opinion. And by this meanes you shall make evident to the King, the will which you say you have to obey his Majesty, counselling you for as much as I desire your well doing, that this is the best for you to do, without looking for any more open commandement: otherwise assure your selfe, there can but evill come of it, and that his Majesty would be obeyed. And thus I pray God to advise you, and give you hi • holy grace.

closer.dateline: From Grenoble the sixt of December, 1572.

div.head: THE ANSWER OF THE Gentlemen, Captaines, Burgesses, and other being in the Town of Rochell, to the commandements that have been given them in the name of the King, to receive garrisons.
div.p:
WE the Gentlemen, Captaines, Burgesses, and other now being in this Towne of Rochell, doe give
answer to you Mounsieur N. and to such commandements as you give us in the name of his Majesty, that we cannot acknowledge that, that which is signified unto us, and the Proclamation which you require that wee should cause to bee published, doe proceed from his Majesty. And thereof we call to witnesse his Majesty himselfe, his Letters of the 22. and 24. of August, his owne signet, and the publishing of the same Letters, by the which his said Majesty layeth all the fault of all the trouble lately hapned, & of the cruel slaughter done at Paris, upon those of the house of Guise, protesting that hee had enough to do to keepe himselfe safe within his Castell of Louure with those of his Guard. And we shal never suffer our selves to be perswaded that so foule an enterprise and so barbarous a slaughter hath at any time entred into the mind of his Majesty, much lesse that the same hath been done by his expresse commandement, as the paper importeth which
you have exhibited unto us, nor that his Majesty hath been so ill advised, as himself to cut off his own armes, or to defile the sacred wedding of Madame his own sister with the shedding of so much noble & innocent bloud, and with the shame of so cruell a fact to stain the nation of France and the bloud royall, which hath heretofore ever among al nations born the name of franke and courteous: nor that he hath had mind to deliver matter to writers to set forth a tragical history such as antiquity hath never heard speake of the like, and such as posterity cannot report without horror. But that it was first layd at Rome, and afterward hatched at Paris, by the authors of all the troubles of France. And howsoever it be, we are ready to maintaine that out of the mouth of his Majesty doth not proceed hot and cold, white and blacke, and that hee doth not now say one thing, and by and by another, as hee should doe if the paper that you present unto us had passed from him, protesting
that he will inviolably keepe his Edict, and immediately breaking the same in declaring that he commanded those murders to be committed, having also made protestation before, that it is to his great griefe, and done by the outrage and violence of those of Guise, against whom he was not able to make speedy resistance in time, as his Majesty desired. And in this quarrell, wee the Gentlemen, Captaines, and other that make you this answer, are ready to try it by combate man to man, or otherwise, to maintain the honour of our King against all those that so prophane holy things, and as much as in them lyeth do by such words and titles villainously defile the excellence of his Majesty, and of the noble Princes of his bloud. Which we may right well conjecture & estimate, by the slaughters that are yet in doing, as well in the Town of Paris, as else-where, upon so many Noblemen, Gentlemen and other, men, women and children, and upon a great number of young
schollars (the maintenance under God, of Realmes and Commonweales in time to come) and by many other barbarous, unnaturall and unmanly acts generally committed. We thinke therefore and judge that herein treason is enterprised against the person of his Majesty, and of my Lords his brethren, and that the Guisians mean to invade the Crown of the Realme, as they have of long time practised, and howsoever it be, we say that his Majesty is forced by the power that they have taken upon them, and usurped, by meanes of the rebellious stirre of the Commons of Paris. As for that which they say, that the Admirall and those of the Religion had conspired against the Kings Majesty and his brethren; these bee allegations of as great truth, and of as good likelihood, as their manner of proceeding in justice hath been orderly, beginning at execution before examination of the fact. But it is now no need to tarry
for time to discover it, for the matter is plaine to be seene with eye, and groaped with hand, and all those of the Romish Religion that have remaining any drop of nature of man, doe confesse it and hold downe their heads for shame, cursing both with heart and mouth the cruell executers of this abominable enterprise, and the wicked disturbers of common quiet, which can yet no more suffer, than they hitherto have done, that this poore Realme should long enjoy the benefit of that peace, which the King alone, next under God, had wisely caused to be made, and to be accordingly observed, whereof this Realme began to feele the good taste, to the great contentment of all persons, except the enemies of peace and of this Realme, namely, the Guisians. Finally, when his Majesty being out of their hands and power, shall declare what is his pleasure, we will endevour us to obey him in all things, wherein our consciences,
which are dedicate to God alone, shal not be wounded, a true christian resolution in which case wee will rather forsake the earth than heaven, and our fraile and transitory houses rather than the heavenly mansions. But hitherto the law of Nature, and the duty that we owe to our naturall Prince, to the preservation of his Crowne, and to the safety of our lives, our wives and children, doth command us to stand upon our guard, and not to put to our selves in the mercy of those that have received the same bloudy commission from the Guisians, under the pretended name of the King to use us in the same manner as they have wickedly, trayterously, and unnaturally done to those about his Majesty, and as it were under his wings, and under the skirts of his robe, which the traytors strangers have stained with the true French bloud, without that his Majesty hath been able to remedy it, nor to stay their cursed attempts: so much lesse is he able now so farre off
to defend us as he would, which his Majesties good will being knowne unto us, doth arme us for our defence, and for the safeguard of our lives, and for the priviledges which he hath given us, untill such time as he shall be able by himselfe to defend us against his enemies and ours.
